docs.lead_paragraph: Call it death panel redux. It did not take long for Republicans in Congress to start arguing on Tuesday that a federal task force's new recommendations on breast cancer screening had confirmed the worst fears of people who oppose a government role in medical decision making.
docs.abstract: Rep David Camp, Michigan Republican, says federal tax force's new recommendations on breast cancer screening confirms that government will play role in regulating insurance offerings under health care bill passed by House; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Call it death panel redux.     It did not take long for Republicans in Congress to start arguing on Tuesday that a federal task force's new recommendations on breast cancer screening had confirmed the worst fears of people who oppose a government...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Tuesday that he was close to unveiling his health care bill and that Democrats remained committed to passing it. But asked if he had the 60 votes needed to bring up the bill for debate on the Senate floor, Mr. Reid was not entirely certain.

headline.main: Reid Says Bill Is Coming, And Hopes Votes Follow

headline.main: Republicans Say Cancer Screening Guidelines Portend Medical Rationing

docs.abstract: Republicans in Congress argue that a federal task force's new recommendations on breast cancer screening foreshadow the government rationing of medical care.

docs.lead_paragraph: This afternoon a group of 23 prominent economists -- including two Nobel laureates as well as previous members of both Democratic and Republican presidential administrations -- sent a letter to President Obama about the priorities for health care reform. The letter appears below.

headline.main: Economists' Letter to Obama on Health Care Reform

docs.abstract: This afternoon a group of 23 high-profile economists wrote President Obama about the fiscal priorities for health care reform.
docs.snippet: This afternoon a group of 23 high-profile economists wrote President Obama about the fiscal priorities for health care reform.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tom Daschle, the former Senate majority leader and confidant to President Obama who would have been his health secretary but for a tax controversy, is jumping from one law firm, Alston & Bird, to a bigger one with global reach, DLA Piper, to play a larger role in international issues.

headline.main: Daschle Plans Move to Global Firm

docs.abstract: The former Senate majority leader decides to join a firm with more of an international approach.
docs.snippet: The former Senate majority leader decides to join a firm with more of an international approach.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Tuesday that he was close to unveiling his health care bill and that Democrats remained committed to passing it. But when asked if he had the 60 votes needed to bring up the bill for debate on the Senate floor, Mr. Reid was not entirely certain.

headline.main: Reid Says He's Close to Unveiling Health Bill

docs.abstract: Senator Reid says he close to unveiling his health care bill, but acknowledges he is not certain he has 60 votes to bring up for for debate on the Senate floor.
docs.snippet: Senator Reid says he close to unveiling his health care bill, but acknowledges he is not certain he has 60 votes to bring up for for debate on the Senate floor.

docs.lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner is once again facing the wrath of opinionland, this time over his actions as head of the New York Federal Reserve last year, when he agreed to pay "A.I.G.'s partners 100 cents on the dollar to tear up their contracts with the insurance giant."
docs.abstract: Timothy Geithner is coming under fire for paying A.I.G.'s partners 100 cents on the dollar.
docs.snippet: Timothy Geithner is coming under fire for paying A.I.G.'s partners 100 cents on the dollar.

docs.lead_paragraph: Update: For a correction, and more on this topic, see above.
docs.abstract: Why health care reform will make losers out of a third of the uninsured.
docs.snippet: Why health care reform will make losers out of a third of the uninsured.

docs.lead_paragraph: Arguing that the political winds are shifting away from the support necessary for an overhaul, one Wall Street analyst is now predicting Congress will not pass any significant health care legislation anytime soon.

headline.main: Analyst Doubts Health Overhaul Can Pass

docs.abstract: The political winds are shifting away from the support necessary for a health care overhaul, a Wall Street analyst writes.
docs.snippet: The political winds are shifting away from the support necessary for a health care overhaul, a Wall Street analyst writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two conservative groups formally asked federal prosecutors to investigate what they said were potentially illegal lobbying activities by the president of the Service Employees International Union.

headline.main: Inquiry Into Labor Leader Is Requested
headline.print_headline: Inquiry Into Labor Leader Is Requested

docs.snippet: Two conservative groups formally asked federal prosecutors to investigate what they said were potentially illegal lobbying activities by the president of the Service Employees International Union.
